newsitem.title: USA: U.S. YIELD CURVE--Mkt buys 10-yr notes, shuns TIPS.
newsitem.headline: U.S. YIELD CURVE--Mkt buys 10-yr notes, shuns TIPS.

text.p: It started last year with just bad jokes.
But now, investors are not only railing against the U.S. Treasury's 10-year inflation-protected securities (TIPS), but many have started dumping them from their portfolios.
"As long as inflation doesn't look like a problem, you would do better buying fixed (10-year notes) versus indexed ones," said Sam Kahan, chief economist and president of ASK Financial Research Ltd.

Money market participants said numerous fixed-income funds sold blocks of the 10-year inflation-indexed securities earlier this week. They added that the amount perceived to have been sold ranged from $250 million to $1.0 billion.

Investors seem to be content with the view that inflation is not a problem, evidenced by a 0.3 percent decline in the May producer price index and just a scant 0.1 percent increase in the May consumer price index.
The low-inflation scenario combined with the Treasury's decision last week to do away with two regular 10-year note auctions led to a large rally in the nominal 10-year note.
The buying spree brought yields on the issue down to 6.40 percent on Wednesday from near 7.0 percent in mid-April.
In contrast, the 10-year TIPS, which was sold at 3.65 percent on April 8, was at 3.64 percent late Wednesday. It was at 3.55 percent on Friday.
Consequently, the spread between the nominal and 10-year TIPS has narrowed to its lowest level ever at 275 basis points from 333 basis points in late March.
"Unless inflation picks up, there is risk to further spread widening and (TIPS) underperformance," said Hussein Malik, Treasury market strategist at J.P. Morgan & Co.
"The 10-year sector has outperformed the rest of the market as well, but still, (a narrowing of the spread by) 55 basis points is pretty extreme."
Also, traders said the lack of liquidity in the TIPS is a point of concern among players.
On Wednesday afternoon, for instance, GovPX trading volume in the 10-year TIPS was $62 million against the over $4.0 billion traded in regular 10-year notes.
"There is a limited audience who can trade and buy (TIPS)," said Bill Kirby, co-head trader at Prudential Securities Inc. "They are still not something the overall public is comfortable with.
"No one knows how to hedge them. We are still going through the feeling out process," he added.
Kirby and other players suspect that once the Treasury develops a TIPS yield curve, the inflation-linked securities might become more popular.
So far, Treasury has sold only 10-year TIPS.

The inaugural auction on January 29 for $7.0 billion brought in heavy demand and a lower than expected yield of 3.449 percent. The Treasury re-opened the issue and added $8.0 billion of the notes on April 8 with a 3.65 percent return over inflation. Demand was considerably lighter.
In July, Treasury will sell five-year TIPS and in 1998, Treasury will sell 30-year TIPS.
"Once we get a curve, we will be able to put together something," Kirby said. "Now, there's a limited audience."
